name: Pistole M
description: A East German copy of the Pistolet Makarova.  It uses the 9x18mm cartridge, which remains in use among various former Soviet countries.

name: Vz. 82
description: The Vz.82, also referred to as the CZ 83 was Czechoslovakia's attempted at making an improved version of the Soviet Makarov pistol.  It features a larger magazine, better finish, and much improved ergonomics.

name: Makarov PMM
description: A modernized all steel version of the Pistolet Makarova.  It features a wider frame and hand grip to accommodate double stack style magazines.  It uses the 9x18mm cartridge, which remains in use among various former Soviet countries.

name: PB Silent Pistol
description: A Soviet era suppressed pistol based on the Pistolet Makarova design.  It uses the 9x18mm cartridge, which remains in use among various former Soviet countries.

name: Fort-12
description: A Ukrainian semi-auto pistol developed after the fall of the Soviet Union.  It uses the 9x18mm cartridge, which remains in use among various former Soviet countries.

name: Stechkin APS
description: A Soviet era select fire machine pistol.  It uses the 9x18mm cartridge, which remains in use among various former Soviet countries.

name: Borz
description: Chechen for 'wolf', the borz is a crudely made submachine gun first produced in Chechnya in the early 90's.  While most guns differ in exact design, they are mostly based on the Armenian K6-92.  Just a much cheaper, simpler version.

name: PP-91 Kedr
description: A simply designed Russian select-fire submachine gun.  It sees use among various Russian police agencies and private security companies.

name: PP-19 Bizon
description: The Bizon is lightweight select-fire submachine gun based on the AKS-74.  One of the most notable features is it's large underbarrel helical-feed magazine which is sometimes mistaken for a grenade launcher.
